mohamed.name: The Education God
mohamed.title: Education God
mohamed.catchphrase_correct: Excellent! You are demonstrating the hallmarks of a great radiologist!
mohamed.catchphrase_wrong: Let us revisit the fundamentals together, shall we?

questions.question: Which principle governs minimizing radiation exposure to patients in radiology?
questions.explanation: ALARA — As Low As Reasonably Achievable — is the cornerstone radiation safety principle in radiology.

questions.question: What is the standard residency length for diagnostic radiology in the US after internship?
questions.explanation: Diagnostic radiology residency is 4 years after a 1-year internship (5 years total post-medical school).

questions.question: Which organization sets the core curriculum and milestones for radiology residents?
questions.explanation: The ACGME (Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education) sets milestones and accreditation standards for radiology programs.

questions.question: What does 'ACR' stand for in American radiology?
questions.explanation: ACR stands for the American College of Radiology, the professional society governing radiology practice in the US.

questions.question: In radiology education, what does 'case-based learning' primarily emphasize?
options: Learning from real clinical imaging cases with attending guidance
questions.explanation: Case-based learning with direct attending supervision is the cornerstone of radiology resident education as emphasized by ACGME.

kasprzak.name: The Business God
kasprzak.title: Business God
kasprzak.catchphrase_correct: NOW that is good for the bottom line! I like how you think!
kasprzak.catchphrase_wrong: That answer would have cost us money. Study your billing codes!

questions.question: What does 'RVU' stand for in radiology physician compensation?
questions.explanation: RVU (Relative Value Unit) is the fundamental unit used by Medicare to calculate physician payment for services rendered.

questions.question: Which coding system is used to report radiology procedures for billing in the US?
questions.explanation: CPT (Current Procedural Terminology) codes are maintained by the AMA and used to report radiology procedures for billing.

questions.question: What is 'prior authorization' in radiology practice?
options: A patient's written consent for imaging
Approval from insurance before performing certain imaging studies
A radiologist's preliminary read before final report
questions.explanation: Prior authorization is insurance carrier approval required before certain imaging studies to ensure reimbursement.

questions.question: In value-based radiology, what metric is most directly tied to quality reporting?
options: Number of studies read per day
questions.explanation: MIPS (Merit-based Incentive Payment System) under MACRA ties physician payment to quality, value, and practice improvement.

questions.question: How is professional component billing handled in an academic radiology department?
options: Technical component only — no professional billing
Professional component billed separately by radiologists (modifier 26)
Global billing always includes both components
Split billing is illegal in academic centers
questions.explanation: In academic hospitals, the professional component (interpretation) is billed separately using modifier 26, while the hospital bills the technical component.

kayat.name: The Prostate God
kayat.title: Prostate God
kayat.catchphrase_correct: Magnifico! You understand the prostate like a true maestro!
kayat.catchphrase_wrong: Meu amigo, you must go back and read your PI-RADS guidelines!

questions.question: On prostate MRI, which sequence is dominant for peripheral zone lesion assessment per PI-RADS v2.1?
questions.explanation: Per PI-RADS v2.1, DWI is the dominant sequence for the peripheral zone (PZ). T2W is dominant for the transition zone (TZ).

questions.question: A PI-RADS 4 lesion implies what likelihood of clinically significant prostate cancer?
questions.explanation: PI-RADS 4 lesions carry > 60% likelihood of clinically significant cancer (Gleason ≥ 3+4 = Grade Group 2 or higher).

questions.question: Where is the majority of clinically significant prostate cancer located?
questions.explanation: Approximately 70–75% of prostate cancers arise in the peripheral zone, though ~20–25% occur in the transition zone.

questions.question: What is the normal T2 signal appearance of the peripheral zone on prostate MRI?
questions.explanation: The normal PZ appears T2 hyperintense. Cancer appears as T2 hypointense foci — loss of the normal bright signal.

questions.question: Which biopsy technique fuses mpMRI with real-time ultrasound for targeted prostate sampling?
questions.explanation: MRI-TRUS fusion biopsy combines anatomic targeting from mpMRI with real-time TRUS guidance for sampling of PI-RADS 3–5 lesions.

ramaiya.name: The Cancer God
ramaiya.title: Cancer God — Mini Boss
ramaiya.catchphrase_correct: Ha! You might actually survive this fellowship after all!
ramaiya.catchphrase_wrong: By the great RECIST criteria... that was absolutely painful to witness.

questions.question: Per RECIST 1.1, what is the minimum short-axis diameter for a lymph node to be a measurable target lesion?
questions.explanation: Per RECIST 1.1, lymph nodes must be ≥15 mm short axis to qualify as measurable target lesions.

questions.question: What percentage DECREASE in sum of target lesion diameters defines Partial Response (PR) per RECIST 1.1?
questions.explanation: A ≥30% decrease from baseline in the sum of longest diameters of target lesions = Partial Response per RECIST 1.1.

questions.question: Which response criteria are preferred for immunotherapy (checkpoint inhibitor) tumor assessment?
questions.explanation: iRECIST/irRECIST accounts for pseudoprogression seen with immunotherapy, where tumors may initially appear larger before responding.

questions.question: In RECIST 1.1, what is the maximum number of target lesions that can be selected?
questions.explanation: RECIST 1.1 allows a maximum of 5 target lesions total (up to 2 per organ) — reduced from 10 in RECIST 1.0.

questions.question: Per RECIST 1.1, what defines Progressive Disease (PD)?
options: ≥20% increase in sum of diameters (min 5 mm absolute) OR new lesions
Any new lesion regardless of target lesion change
questions.explanation: PD = ≥20% increase in sum of longest diameters from nadir (minimum 5 mm absolute increase) OR unequivocal progression of non-target lesions OR new lesions.

questions.question: What are the Choi response criteria primarily used for?
options: GIST on tyrosine kinase inhibitors — accounts for density + size changes
questions.explanation: Choi criteria for GIST on imatinib: response = ≥10% decrease in size OR ≥15% decrease in CT density (HU) — captures early response before size change.

questions.question: In a GIST patient on imatinib, which CT finding suggests treatment response BEFORE size change?
questions.explanation: Responding GIST lesions become hypodense/cystic on CT due to myxoid degeneration and necrosis, often before size decreases.

questions.question: Modified RECIST (mRECIST) for hepatocellular carcinoma measures:
options: Only the viable (arterial phase enhancing) tumor component
T2 signal change on MRI only
questions.explanation: mRECIST measures only the viable (arterially-enhancing) tumor portion, accounting for locoregional therapies that cause central necrosis.

questions.question: A patient on sorafenib for HCC shows central necrosis and reduced enhancement but no size change. Per mRECIST this is:
questions.explanation: mRECIST PR = ≥30% decrease in the sum of diameters of viable (enhancing) tumor. Necrosis reducing enhancement qualifies even without overall size change.

questions.question: Which response criteria are used for lymphoma assessment?
questions.explanation: The Lugano Classification (updated Cheson 2014 criteria) uses PET-CT for lymphoma response assessment — complete metabolic response = Deauville score 1–2.

tirumani.name: The Clinical God
tirumani.title: Division Chief — The Clinical God
tirumani.catchphrase_correct: As Division Chief, I hereby grant you safe passage. You have earned it.
tirumani.catchphrase_wrong: You DARE challenge the Division Chief with THAT answer?! Unacceptable!

questions.question: Pseudoprogression in immunotherapy-treated patients refers to:
options: True tumor growth requiring treatment change
Apparent tumor growth due to immune cell infiltration — later shows true response
Radiation recall reaction in previously treated fields
questions.explanation: Pseudoprogression = apparent early tumor enlargement from immune infiltration, which later demonstrates true response. Critical not to prematurely stop effective immunotherapy.

questions.question: The hallmark imaging feature of HCC on contrast-enhanced MRI is:
options: Arterial phase hyperenhancement with portal venous/delayed phase washout
questions.explanation: HCC hallmark = arterial phase hyperenhancement (APHE) + washout appearance on portal venous/delayed phase. This is LR-5 (definite HCC) under LI-RADS.

questions.question: In a patient with known ovarian cancer and new peritoneal implants, which response criteria should be used?
questions.explanation: RECIST 1.1 remains the standard for solid tumor response including gynecologic malignancies. PERCIST uses PET for metabolic response.

questions.question: What is the most common site of metastatic disease in patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)?
questions.explanation: GISTs most commonly metastasize to the liver and peritoneum. Lymph node metastases are actually uncommon — unlike most other GI tumors.

questions.question: What early imaging change on CT indicates response to imatinib in GIST before size change?
options: Decrease in lesion T2 signal on MRI
questions.explanation: Responding GIST lesions decrease in CT density (Choi criteria) before demonstrating size decrease. Using RECIST alone can underestimate response.

questions.question: What is the LI-RADS system used for?
options: Liver cancer screening in the general population
Standardized reporting of liver observations in patients at risk for HCC
questions.explanation: LI-RADS (Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System) standardizes reporting of liver observations on CT/MRI in patients at risk for HCC (cirrhosis, chronic HBV).

questions.question: Which LI-RADS v2018 category denotes definite HCC?
questions.explanation: LR-5 = definitely HCC. LR-4 = probably HCC. LR-M = probably or definitely malignant but not HCC-specific. LR-3 = intermediate probability.

questions.question: What imaging finding defines 'washout appearance' in HCC on CT/MRI?
options: Lesion becomes brighter than liver on delayed phase
Lesion becomes hypodense/hypointense relative to liver on portal venous or delayed phase
Complete loss of enhancement in all phases
questions.explanation: Washout appearance = lesion becomes hypodense (CT) or hypointense (MRI) relative to liver background on portal venous or delayed phases, after arterial hyperenhancement.

questions.question: A new adrenal lesion in a patient with known lung cancer. What non-contrast CT attenuation threshold most favors a lipid-rich adenoma over metastasis?
questions.explanation: ≤10 HU on non-contrast CT = lipid-rich adrenal adenoma with ~98% specificity. Most metastases are > 10 HU. Values > 20 HU warrant further evaluation (washout CT or MRI).

questions.question: What is the clinical significance of 'oligometastatic' disease in oncologic imaging?
options: Diffuse metastatic spread — palliative care only
Limited metastatic burden (typically ≤5 lesions) where curative-intent local therapy may be considered
Micrometastases too small to detect on imaging
A single large metastasis requiring surgery
questions.explanation: Oligometastatic disease (typically ≤5 lesions, limited organ involvement) represents an intermediate state where aggressive local therapies (SBRT, resection) may achieve long-term disease control or cure.
